keyTakeAways: A man, Ian Cleary, was sentenced to two to four years in prison after being found guilty of sexually assaulting a woman, Shannon Keeler, at Gettysburg College in 2013.
The victim, Shannon Keeler, pursued charges for over a decade, highlighting systemic failures in prosecuting campus sexual assault cases.
Cleary's guilty plea, remorse, and history of mental illness led the judge to impose a sentence below state guidelines.
Cleary sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you' in 2019 as part of a 12-step program seeking atonement, which retraumatized the victim.
The case exemplifies the difficulty of tracking and prosecuting campus sexual assaults due to lack of evidence, long time gaps, and institutional reluctance.
The victim's prolonged struggle underscores the need for reform in how institutions respond to sexual assault and support survivors.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In 2013, Ian Cleary sexually assaulted Shannon Keeler at Gettysburg College. The case remained unprosecuted for over a decade due to institutional reluctance and lost evidence. In 2019, Cleary sent a Facebook message stating 'So I raped you,' which retraumatized Keeler and reignited her efforts. After a three-year search and Cleary’s extradition from France in 2024, he pleaded guilty and was sentenced to two to four years in prison by Senior Judge Kevin Hess. The judge cited Cleary’s remorse and mental health history as mitigating factors. Keeler, who had waited 12 years for justice, described the case as a long struggle against a system that failed her. This case reflects broader challenges in prosecuting campus sexual assault, including evidence destruction, prosecutorial inertia, and the emotional toll on survivors.
title: Man Sentenced to Prison for 2013 Campus Rape After Decades of Inaction
